parent.body_html: As a creep, I resent you associating me with bots.

post.body:
As a lurker on reddit, I used to just browse by hot or whatever my feed gave me. On Ruqqus Im having a blast sorting by new and discovering posts as they come up.

 Its surprising how a difference in culture makes this an enjoyable experience, im contributing to threads i would never see on reddit. if you havent tried it yet, i would really reccomend it. 
Ive posted more in the last day on Ruqqus, than the last month on Reddit.
post.body_html:
As a lurker on reddit, I used to just browse by hot or whatever my feed gave me. On Ruqqus Im having a blast sorting by new and discovering posts as they come up.

Its surprising how a difference in culture makes this an enjoyable experience, im contributing to threads i would never see on reddit. if you havent tried it yet, i would really reccomend it. Ive posted more in the last day on Ruqqus, than the last month on Reddit.
post.title: Browsing by new is actually.... fun?

post.body:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our [Terms of Service](/help/terms).

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we ~~decided to crack down on hate speech~~ developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
2. A specific place or time, and
3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam
post.body_html:
About two weeks ago, we banned a few individuals for posting calls to genocide, under the "no incitement to violence" clause of our Terms of Service.

Since then, we've received a fair amount of criticism and backlash for this being an overstep into Constitutionally protected speech. As a result of this criticism, the Ruqqus admin team has taken some time for a lot of internal discussion and debate on policy. Where is the line between Constitutionally protected general internet assholery, and unprotected advocacy of illegal activity?

We want to clarify our stance on this, so that we can ensure internal consistency , and so that you can have a good idea of what to expect from us.

Since we want to protect as much free speech as possible, we looked at US laws and Supreme Court cases. Admittedly, none of it focused on internet speech, but we did our best to adapt and modify Supreme Court logic to online behavior.

The end result is that we decided to crack down on hate speech developed a three part test which we will be using as an internal guideline for whether or not something counts as incitement to violence. This will allow us to evaluate content without having to consider motivations, political factors, or our own internal biases.

To count as incitement or planning of violence, a piece of content should include:

  1. A harmful action, such as "kill", "shoot", "lynch", "gas", etc, and
  2. A specific place or time, and
  3. A specific person, group, or demographic

With an explicit exception for statements regarding ethically permissible defense of yourself or others.

Please note that this is an internal guideline, not an ironclad rule. If we have good reason to believe that something is a credible threat, we will take appropriate action even if it doesn't necessarily meet all three points.

We have also revisited the bans that sparked this whole discussion. We reevaluated the conduct according to the new guidelines, and determined that it does not meet the threshold for incitement to violence. Accordingly, those bans will be reversed.

Thanks for being patient as we continue to develop and improve this platform together.

-Adam
post.title: Free speech and Calls to Violence

parent.body:
---end of transcript---

There is a third thing I'd like to add to the discussion: User-powered filtering.

Other social media platforms infantilize their users, spoon-feeding them only "acceptable", politically correct, vanilla content. We see this with the Twitter trending section. They routinely purge the Trending bar of anything that might be sensitive or offensive, leaving it as a perpetual mix of boring trash and Orange Man Bad. We see this with Reddit's redesign, pushing paid promotions and other intellectually bankrupt content to the forefront of the site.

Ruqqus takes a different tactic, giving users the power to decide for themselves what they wish to see. All of the content filtering options are user settings, and are off by default (with the sole exception of the NSFW filter, which is active by default for legal reasons).

At Ruqqus, we don't spoon-feed you "safe" "acceptable" posts. We let you choose what you want to see.
parent.body_html:
---end of transcript---

There is a third thing I'd like to add to the discussion: User-powered filtering.

Other social media platforms infantilize their users, spoon-feeding them only "acceptable", politically correct, vanilla content. We see this with the Twitter trending section. They routinely purge the Trending bar of anything that might be sensitive or offensive, leaving it as a perpetual mix of boring trash and Orange Man Bad. We see this with Reddit's redesign, pushing paid promotions and other intellectually bankrupt content to the forefront of the site.

Ruqqus takes a different tactic, giving users the power to decide for themselves what they wish to see. All of the content filtering options are user settings, and are off by default (with the sole exception of the NSFW filter, which is active by default for legal reasons).

At Ruqqus, we don't spoon-feed you "safe" "acceptable" posts. We let you choose what you want to see.

post.body:
About 95% of this patch was written by you guys. If you're included here and don't already have Codesmith title, give me your Ruqqus name from the github PR page and I will grant it to you.

- Added "Ruqqus" to page metadata more promenently by @crystalvulpine
- Move the Linux documentation written by @rostredd, also by @crystalvulpine
- Improved JSON data for submissions by mpieciak18
- Favicon fixes by @kaijuagenda
- Changed the kick icon, also by @crystalvulpine
- Fixed a typo in the slur list by wp140x
- Fixed a seed data typo by @Foxite
- Date/time improvements, also by @foxite

Also changed some interactions with temporarily banned users and guildmaster actions. Temp-banned users can now continue to moderate their guilds for the duration of their temporary ban, and do not automatically count as inactive for the purposes of guild siege.
post.body_html:
About 95% of this patch was written by you guys. If you're included here and don't already have Codesmith title, give me your Ruqqus name from the github PR page and I will grant it to you.

  • Added "Ruqqus" to page metadata more promenently by @CrystalVulpine
  • Move the Linux documentation written by @Rostredd, also by @CrystalVulpine
  • Improved JSON data for submissions by mpieciak18
  • Favicon fixes by @KaijuAgenda
  • Changed the kick icon, also by @CrystalVulpine
  • Fixed a typo in the slur list by wp140x
  • Fixed a seed data typo by @foxite
  • Date/time improvements, also by @foxite

Also changed some interactions with temporarily banned users and guildmaster actions. Temp-banned users can now continue to moderate their guilds for the duration of their temporary ban, and do not automatically count as inactive for the purposes of guild siege.
post.title: Ruqqus 2.17.7 - The User-Powered Patch

guild.name: foxes

post.body:
As the owner and creator of this guild and /r/EverythingFoxes, I'm not that great of a foxposter. Why? Because I struggle to find any new quality content related to foxes.

However, I've noticed that quite a few others are doing so rather easily. My guess is that they know of some obscure fox websites that you can't really discover unless someone happens to mention it to you. Unfortunately, these people almost always reupload what they find to gfycat, imgur, or i.ruqqus and i.redd.it, and link to that instead, so you can't find the source where they're getting all this content from. My only sources atm are reddit, google, imgur, gfycat, and hourly flops. Those are great for finding long-time popular reposts, but all except the latter are terrible for discovering *new* (quality) content. (Hourly flops is good, but people are clearly getting their content from many more sources than just that, and hourly flops only has pics, no videos/gifs).

So, those of you who find a bunch of new fox pics and gifs all the time, what gives? Where are you getting them from, and where do you find them at?

Edit: Foxposters, show yourselves! I'm pinning this post so people who come to this guild in the future will see it and can find your foxy content sources.

Edit 2: Someone just gave me a bunch of sources:

* [Hourly Fops](https://t.me/HourlyFops)
* [Fennec Friends](https://t.me/FennecFriends)
* [RedTaily](https://t.me/redtaily)
* [Foxposting](https://t.me/foxposting)
* [coolfoxaccount](https://twitter.com/CoolFoxAccount)
* [hourlyFox](https://twitter.com/hourlyFox)
* https://foxrudor.de/
* https://fox-info.net/
* [Juniper](https://www.youtube.com/c/JuniperFox/videos)
* [Alice the Fox](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCiEFbQHfI-iiez0NBr6ZV1g)
* [SaveAFox](https://www.youtube.com/c/SaveAFox)
* [Loki the Red Fox](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvbRv7guDemGXy12jyk4ZzA)

Apparently following these on telegram/twitter will cause the algorithms to find more of them and suggest them to you, so that's how these people always manage to discover these niche accounts/websites.
post.body_html:
As the owner and creator of this guild and /r/EverythingFoxes, I'm not that great of a foxposter. Why? Because I struggle to find any new quality content related to foxes.

However, I've noticed that quite a few others are doing so rather easily. My guess is that they know of some obscure fox websites that you can't really discover unless someone happens to mention it to you. Unfortunately, these people almost always reupload what they find to gfycat, imgur, or i.ruqqus and i.redd.it, and link to that instead, so you can't find the source where they're getting all this content from. My only sources atm are reddit, google, imgur, gfycat, and hourly flops. Those are great for finding long-time popular reposts, but all except the latter are terrible for discovering new (quality) content. (Hourly flops is good, but people are clearly getting their content from many more sources than just that, and hourly flops only has pics, no videos/gifs).

So, those of you who find a bunch of new fox pics and gifs all the time, what gives? Where are you getting them from, and where do you find them at?

Edit: Foxposters, show yourselves! I'm pinning this post so people who come to this guild in the future will see it and can find your foxy content sources.

Edit 2: Someone just gave me a bunch of sources:

  • Hourly Fops
  • Fennec Friends
  • RedTaily
  • Foxposting
  • coolfoxaccount
  • hourlyFox
  • https://foxrudor.de/
  • https://fox-info.net/
  • Juniper
  • Alice the Fox
  • SaveAFox
  • Loki the Red Fox

Apparently following these on telegram/twitter will cause the algorithms to find more of them and suggest them to you, so that's how these people always manage to discover these niche accounts/websites.
post.title: Where are people finding all these pictures and videos of foxes?
